Question 79) A series circuit is formed by a stack, an incandescent lamp and a switching key. When turning on the key, the lamp lights up almost instantly, radiating heat and light. Popularly, the phenomenon of energy irradiation is associated with a wear of the electric current, by crossing the lamp filament, and the speed with which the lamp begins to shine. This explanation is in disagreement with the classic current model.
According to the model mentioned, the fact that the lamp lights up almost instantly is related to the speed with which
A) The electric fluid moves in the circuit.
B) Mobile negative charges cross the circuit.
C) The battery releases mobile loads to the lamp filament.
D) The electric field is established at all points of the circuit.
E) The positive and negative charges clash in the lamp filament.
